segment.source: Sample data on the design surface, and for prototyping
segment.target: Sample data on the design surface, and for prototyping

segment.source: It may be impossible or undesirable (perhaps for reasons of privacy or performance) for your app to display live data on the design surface in Microsoft Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio.
segment.target: It may be impossible or undesirable (perhaps for reasons of privacy or performance) for your app to display live data on the design surface in Microsoft Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio.

segment.source: Sample data on the design surface, and for prototyping
segment.target: Sample data on the design surface, and for prototyping

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: Note The degree to which you need sample data—and how much it will help you—depends on whether your bindings use the {Binding} markup extension or the {x:Bind} markup extension.
segment.target: Note The degree to which you need sample data—and how much it will help you—depends on whether your bindings use the {Binding} markup extension or the {x:Bind} markup extension.

segment.source: The techniques described in this topic are based on the use of a DataContext, so they're only appropriate for {Binding}.
segment.target: The techniques described in this topic are based on the use of a DataContext, so they're only appropriate for {Binding}.

segment.source: But if you're using {x:Bind} then your bindings at least show placeholder values on the design surface (even for items controls), so you don't have quite the same need for sample data.
segment.target: But if you're using {x:Bind} then your bindings at least show placeholder values on the design surface (even for items controls), so you don't have quite the same need for sample data.

segment.source: It may be impossible or undesirable (perhaps for reasons of privacy or performance) for your app to display live data on the design surface in Microsoft Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio.
segment.target: It may be impossible or undesirable (perhaps for reasons of privacy or performance) for your app to display live data on the design surface in Microsoft Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio.

segment.source: In order to have your controls populated with data (so that you can work on your app's layout, templates, and other visual properties), there are various ways in which you can use design-time sample data.
segment.target: In order to have your controls populated with data (so that you can work on your app's layout, templates, and other visual properties), there are various ways in which you can use design-time sample data.

segment.source: Sample data can also be really useful and time-saving if you're building a sketch (or prototype) app.
segment.target: Sample data can also be really useful and time-saving if you're building a sketch (or prototype) app.

segment.source: You can use sample data in your sketch or prototype at run-time to illustrate your ideas without going as far as connecting to real, live data.
segment.target: You can use sample data in your sketch or prototype at run-time to illustrate your ideas without going as far as connecting to real, live data.

segment.source: Setting DataContext in markup
segment.target: Setting DataContext in markup

segment.source: It's a fairly common developer practice to use imperative code (in code-behind) to set a page or user control's DataContext to a view model instance.
segment.target: It's a fairly common developer practice to use imperative code (in code-behind) to set a page or user control's DataContext to a view model instance.

segment.source: But if you do that then your page isn't as "designable" as it could be.
segment.target: But if you do that then your page isn't as "designable" as it could be.

segment.source: The reason is that when your XAML page is opened in Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio, the imperative code that assigns the DataContext value is never run (in fact, none of your code-behind is executed).
segment.target: The reason is that when your XAML page is opened in Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio, the imperative code that assigns the DataContext value is never run (in fact, none of your code-behind is executed).

segment.source: The XAML tools do of course parse your markup and instantiate any objects declared in it, but they don't actually instantiate your page's type itself.
segment.target: The XAML tools do of course parse your markup and instantiate any objects declared in it, but they don't actually instantiate your page's type itself.

segment.source: The result is that you won't see any data in your controls or in the Create Data Binding dialog, and your page will be more challenging to style and to lay out.
segment.target: The result is that you won't see any data in your controls or in the Create Data Binding dialog, and your page will be more challenging to style and to lay out.

segment.source: Sparse design UI.
segment.target: Sparse design UI.

segment.source: The first remedy to try is to comment out that DataContext assignment and set the DataContext in your page markup instead.
segment.target: The first remedy to try is to comment out that DataContext assignment and set the DataContext in your page markup instead.

segment.source: That way, your live data shows up at design-time as well as at run-time.
segment.target: That way, your live data shows up at design-time as well as at run-time.

segment.source: To do this, first open your XAML page.
segment.target: To do this, first open your XAML page.

segment.source: Then, in the Document Outline window, click the root designable element (usually with the label Page) to select it.
segment.target: Then, in the Document Outline window, click the root designable element (usually with the label Page) to select it.

segment.source: In the Properties window, find the DataContext property (inside the Common category), and then click New.
segment.target: In the Properties window, find the DataContext property (inside the Common category), and then click New.

segment.source: Click your view model type from the Select Object dialog box, and then click OK.
segment.target: Click your view model type from the Select Object dialog box, and then click OK.

segment.source: UI for setting DataContext.
segment.target: UI for setting DataContext.

segment.source: Here's what the resulting markup looks like.
segment.target: Here's what the resulting markup looks like.

segment.source: And here’s what the design surface looks like now that your bindings can resolve.
segment.target: And here’s what the design surface looks like now that your bindings can resolve.

segment.source: Notice that the Path picker in the Create Data Binding dialog is now populated, based on the DataContext type and the properties that you can bind to.
segment.target: Notice that the Path picker in the Create Data Binding dialog is now populated, based on the DataContext type and the properties that you can bind to.

segment.source: Designable UI.
segment.target: Designable UI.

segment.source: The Create Data Binding dialog only needs a type to work from, but the bindings need the properties to be initialized with values.
segment.target: The Create Data Binding dialog only needs a type to work from, but the bindings need the properties to be initialized with values.

segment.source: If you don't want to reach out to your cloud service at design-time (due to performance, paying for data transfer, privacy issues, that kind of thing) then your initialization code can check to see whether your app is running in a design tool (such as Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio) and in that case load sample data for use at design-time only.
segment.target: If you don't want to reach out to your cloud service at design-time (due to performance, paying for data transfer, privacy issues, that kind of thing) then your initialization code can check to see whether your app is running in a design tool (such as Visual Studio or Blend for Visual Studio) and in that case load sample data for use at design-time only.

segment.source: You could use a view model locator if you need to pass parameters to your initialization code.
segment.target: You could use a view model locator if you need to pass parameters to your initialization code.

segment.source: A view model locator is a class that you can put into app resources.
segment.target: A view model locator is a class that you can put into app resources.

segment.source: It has a property that exposes the view model, and your page's DataContext binds to that property.
segment.target: It has a property that exposes the view model, and your page's DataContext binds to that property.

segment.source: Another pattern that the locator or the view model can use is dependency injection, which can construct a design-time or a run-time data provider (each of which implements a common interface), as applicable.
segment.target: Another pattern that the locator or the view model can use is dependency injection, which can construct a design-time or a run-time data provider (each of which implements a common interface), as applicable.

segment.source: "Sample data from class", and design-time attributes
segment.target: "Sample data from class", and design-time attributes

segment.source: If for whatever reason none of the options in the previous section work for you then you still have plenty of design-time data options available via XAML tools features and design-time attributes.
segment.target: If for whatever reason none of the options in the previous section work for you then you still have plenty of design-time data options available via XAML tools features and design-time attributes.

segment.source: One good option is the Create Sample Data from Class feature in Blend for Visual Studio.
segment.target: One good option is the Create Sample Data from Class feature in Blend for Visual Studio.

segment.source: You can find that command on one of the buttons at the top of the Data panel.
segment.target: You can find that command on one of the buttons at the top of the Data panel.

segment.source: All you need to do is to specify a class for the command to use.
segment.target: All you need to do is to specify a class for the command to use.

segment.source: The command then does two important things for you.
segment.target: The command then does two important things for you.

segment.source: First, it generates a XAML file that contains sample data suitable for hydrating an instance of your chosen class and all of its members, recursively (in fact, the tooling works equally well with XAML or JSON files).
segment.target: First, it generates a XAML file that contains sample data suitable for hydrating an instance of your chosen class and all of its members, recursively (in fact, the tooling works equally well with XAML or JSON files).

segment.source: Second, it populates the Data panel with the schema of your chosen class.
segment.target: Second, it populates the Data panel with the schema of your chosen class.

segment.source: You can then drag members from the Data panel onto the design surface to perform various tasks.
segment.target: You can then drag members from the Data panel onto the design surface to perform various tasks.

segment.source: Depending on what you drag and where you drop it, you can add bindings to existing controls (using {Binding}), or create new controls and bind them at the same time.
segment.target: Depending on what you drag and where you drop it, you can add bindings to existing controls (using {Binding}), or create new controls and bind them at the same time.

segment.source: In either case, the operation also sets a design-time data context (d:DataContext) for you (if one is not already set) on the layout root of your page.
segment.target: In either case, the operation also sets a design-time data context (d:DataContext) for you (if one is not already set) on the layout root of your page.

segment.source: That design-time data context uses the d:DesignData attribute to get its sample data from the XAML file that was generated (which, by the way, you are free to find in your project and edit so that it contains the sample data you want).
segment.target: That design-time data context uses the d:DesignData attribute to get its sample data from the XAML file that was generated (which, by the way, you are free to find in your project and edit so that it contains the sample data you want).

segment.source: The various xmlns declarations mean that attributes with the d: prefix are interpreted only at design-time and are ignored at run-time.
segment.target: The various xmlns declarations mean that attributes with the d: prefix are interpreted only at design-time and are ignored at run-time.

segment.source: So the d:DataContext attribute only affects the value of the DataContext property at design-time; it has no effect at run-time.
segment.target: So the d:DataContext attribute only affects the value of the DataContext property at design-time; it has no effect at run-time.

segment.source: You can even set both d:DataContext and DataContext in markup if you like.
segment.target: You can even set both d:DataContext and DataContext in markup if you like.

segment.source: d:DataContext will override at design-time, and DataContext will override at run-time.
segment.target: d:DataContext will override at design-time, and DataContext will override at run-time.

segment.source: These same override rules apply to all design-time and run-time attributes.
segment.target: These same override rules apply to all design-time and run-time attributes.

segment.source: The d:DataContext attribute, and all other design-time attributes, are documented in the Design-Time Attributes topic, which is still valid for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.
segment.target: The d:DataContext attribute, and all other design-time attributes, are documented in the Design-Time Attributes topic, which is still valid for Universal Windows Platform (UWP) apps.

segment.source: CollectionViewSource doesn't have a DataContext property, but it does have a Source property.
segment.target: CollectionViewSource doesn't have a DataContext property, but it does have a Source property.

segment.source: Consequently, there's a d:Source property that you can use to set design-time-only sample data on a CollectionViewSource.
segment.target: Consequently, there's a d:Source property that you can use to set design-time-only sample data on a CollectionViewSource.

segment.source: For this to work, you would have a class named , and you would edit the sample data XAML file so that it contains only a Recordings object (with Recording objects inside that), as shown here.
segment.target: For this to work, you would have a class named , and you would edit the sample data XAML file so that it contains only a Recordings object (with Recording objects inside that), as shown here.

segment.source: If you use a JSON sample data file instead of XAML, you must set the Type property.
segment.target: If you use a JSON sample data file instead of XAML, you must set the Type property.

segment.source: So far, we've been using d:DesignData to load design-time sample data from a XAML or JSON file.
segment.target: So far, we've been using d:DesignData to load design-time sample data from a XAML or JSON file.

segment.source: An alternative to that is the d:DesignInstance markup extension, which indicates that the design-time source is based on the class specified by the Type property.
segment.target: An alternative to that is the d:DesignInstance markup extension, which indicates that the design-time source is based on the class specified by the Type property.

segment.source: Here's an example.
segment.target: Here's an example.

segment.source: The IsDesignTimeCreatable property indicates that the design tool should actually create an instance of the class, which implies that the class has a public default constructor, and that it populates itself with data (either real or sample).
segment.target: The IsDesignTimeCreatable property indicates that the design tool should actually create an instance of the class, which implies that the class has a public default constructor, and that it populates itself with data (either real or sample).

segment.source: If you don't set IsDesignTimeCreatable (or if you set it to False) then you won't get sample data displayed on the design surface.
segment.target: If you don't set IsDesignTimeCreatable (or if you set it to False) then you won't get sample data displayed on the design surface.

segment.source: All the design tool does in that case is to parse the class for its bindable properties and display these in the the Data panel and in the Create Data Binding dialog.
segment.target: All the design tool does in that case is to parse the class for its bindable properties and display these in the the Data panel and in the Create Data Binding dialog.

segment.source: Sample data for prototyping
segment.target: Sample data for prototyping

segment.source: For prototyping, you want sample data at both design-time and at run-time.
segment.target: For prototyping, you want sample data at both design-time and at run-time.

segment.source: For that use case, Blend for Visual Studio has the New Sample Data feature.
segment.target: For that use case, Blend for Visual Studio has the New Sample Data feature.

segment.source: You can find that command on one of the buttons at the top of the Data panel.
segment.target: You can find that command on one of the buttons at the top of the Data panel.

segment.source: Instead of specifying a class, you can actually design the schema of your sample data source right in the Data panel.
segment.target: Instead of specifying a class, you can actually design the schema of your sample data source right in the Data panel.

segment.source: You can also edit sample data values in the Data panel: there's no need to open and edit a file (although, you can still do that if you prefer).
segment.target: You can also edit sample data values in the Data panel: there's no need to open and edit a file (although, you can still do that if you prefer).

segment.source: The New Sample Data feature uses DataContext, and not d:DataContext, so that the sample data is available when you run your sketch or prototype as well as while you're designing it.
segment.target: The New Sample Data feature uses DataContext, and not d:DataContext, so that the sample data is available when you run your sketch or prototype as well as while you're designing it.

segment.source: And the Data panel really speeds up your designing and binding tasks.
segment.target: And the Data panel really speeds up your designing and binding tasks.

segment.source: For example, simply dragging a collection property from the Data panel onto the design surface generates a data-bound items control and the necessary templates, all ready to build and run.
segment.target: For example, simply dragging a collection property from the Data panel onto the design surface generates a data-bound items control and the necessary templates, all ready to build and run.

segment.source: Sample data for prototyping.
segment.target: Sample data for prototyping.
